title: 109_hr3909
content: SHORT TITLE, PURPOSE. The "Hurricane Check Cashing Relief Act of 2005" aims to help victims of 2005 hurricanes who are facing financial difficulties due to closed banks, inaccessible records, lack of ATM access, identification issues, or other hurricane-related challenges. The "Hurricane Check Cashing Relief Act of 2005" assists victims of 2005 hurricanes who cannot access funds at banks or credit unions due to the disaster. Emergency authority granted to guarantee checks cashed for victims of certain 2005 hurricanes. The FDIC is required to establish an emergency program to indemnify insured depository institutions for losses incurred from cashing checks for individuals affected by certain 2005 hurricanes in specific states. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief Act allows for payments up to $2,000 for uncollectible checks or share drafts issued after August 25, 2005. The NCUA must establish an emergency program for insured credit unions to obtain commitments under certain conditions. The NCUA must establish an emergency program for insured credit unions to obtain indemnification for losses up to $2,000 for uncollectible checks or share drafts issued after August 25, 2005 in disaster-affected areas. The National Credit Union Administration will use available funds to make payments to insured credit unions as part of an emergency program. Insured credit unions are allowed to cash checks for individuals affected by disasters, regardless of membership restrictions. Additionally, the Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow for additional transfers to cover relief efforts related to hurricanes in 2005. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer surplus funds to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration to meet payment requirements under the Hurricane Check Cashing Relief Act in response to the 2005 hurricanes. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer surplus funds to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration in proportion to payment requirements under the Hurricane Check Cashing Relief Act of 2005. The Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each bank pays, with a maximum transfer limit specified. The Board will issue guidance to carry out the purposes of the section and reduce fraud after consulting with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration. Federal reserve banks are limited to transferring $200,000,000 under subparagraph (A) and are prohibited from replenishing their surplus fund by that amount. The purpose of this Act is to minimize loss, ensure due diligence in check verification, and provide guidance to meet indemnification requirements for insured depository institutions and credit unions during emergency circumstances like the 2005 hurricanes. The Act aims to facilitate indemnification processes for insured depository institutions and credit unions during emergencies, allowing the recovery of indemnification payments from these institutions if they collect on the check. The Act facilitates indemnification for insured depository institutions and credit unions during emergencies, requiring compliance with guidance conditions and limiting indemnification to $2,000 per individual per institution. The Board of Governors defines terms for the Act. The Act defines key terms such as "Board," "insured credit union," and "insured depository institution." It also includes a rule of construction to clarify that the Act does not affect the rights of institutions regarding fraudulent activities. The provisions of this section apply to checks presented to insured depository institutions or insured credit unions from August 25, 2005, to November 15, 2005, with a possible 60-day extension if deemed necessary due to the impact of the 2005 hurricane disasters on financial intermediation. The programs established under this section may need an extension to meet the immediate needs of disaster victims, with notice published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before the end of the specified period.
